Canada is one of the few countries in the world to hold vast expanses of intact natural areas, and is well known for its magnificent natural scenery and wealth of wildlife.

National Wildlife Areas and Migratory Bird Sanctuaries, totaling over 12.4 million hectares, make up the protected areas network managed by Environment and Climate Change Canada. http://ow.ly/V1ft300O81I

http://ow.ly/KaDj30167iW

caption_original:
Proudly Serving Canadians: Did you know tiny transmitters and patience revealed an endangered sapsucker habitat? 

University of British Columbia graduate student Julien and Environment and Climate Change Canada researcher Kathy attached 29 tiny tail feather transmitters on the endangered Williamson’s Sapsucker and collected 1412 visual observations of foraging and communication behaviour to learn more about their critical habitat requirements. http://ow.ly/cgbc301dEea
caption_cleaned: Proudly Serving Canadians: Did you know tiny transmitters and patience revealed an endangered sapsucker habitat? University of British Columbia graduate student Julien and Environment and Climate Change Canada researcher Kathy attached tiny tail feather transmitters on the endangered Williamson’s Sapsucker and collected visual observations of foraging and communication behaviour to learn more about their critical habitat requirements.

caption_original:
The Bartholomew River, which runs through the Miramichi region of New Brunswick, has long been a favourite destination for anglers. The wild Atlantic salmon that ply its waters support recreational fisheries and are an important food source for Indigenous communities.

Environment and Climate Change Canada is partnering with the Nature Conservancy of Canada to protect the Bartholomew River and restore and enhance this important salmon habitat. Protecting the river and its adjacent forestland from future development will improve water quality and help to regulate the water temperature of the river, improving fish health. http://ow.ly/pNH8301ILpQ
caption_cleaned: The Bartholomew River, which runs through the Miramichi region of New Brunswick, has long been a favourite destination for anglers. The wild Atlantic salmon that ply its waters support recreational fisheries and are an important food source for Indigenous communities. Environment and Climate Change Canada is partnering with the Nature Conservancy of Canada to protect the Bartholomew River and restore and enhance this important salmon habitat. Protecting the river and its adjacent forestland from future development will improve water quality and help to regulate the water temperature of the river, improving fish health.

caption_original: Celebrate Canada’s 149th birthday with a free visit to some of the country’s natural and cultural treasures!
